bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Sergeant and Mrs. J. A. Sabatini, December 29, 1947

div1.p: Hench thanks the Sabatinis for allowing Lawrence Reed and himself to visit their apartment in the Army War College, which contains the room where Walter Reed died. He requests a sketch of the floor plan for his collection.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Sergeant and Mrs. J. A. Sabatini, December 29, 1947
div1.opener:
December 29, 1947
Sergeant and Mrs. J. A. Sabatini
Apartment 4, Second Floor
Building 56-B
Army War College
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Sergeant and Mrs. Sabatini:
div1.p:
You were very kind to let me visit your apartment last month when
I came with General W. L. Reed to visit the one room of your apartment in
which General Reed's father, Major Walter Reed, died in 1902. We told you
that at that time, the building in which you now live was a small Army hos-
pital. Major Walter Reed, perhaps the most distinguished Army physician in
the history of the United States Army, the “conqueror of yellow fever” developed
an acute suppurative appendicitis and was cared for in the room which is now
your parlor. He died in that room. (If you hear any ghostly sounds at night
in that room you will know that you have a most distinguished ghost.)

The places where great men live and die will always be of interest
to historians and I and the Walter Reed Memorial Association were anxious to
locate this room. It was identified by General Albert E. Truby, now of
San Francisco, who visited this room with General Reed last summer. I enclose
some copies of the photographs we took of your room. Should you wish more
I should be glad to send you some.

The Walter Reed Memorial Association has asked General Truby to pre-
pare a report identifying the old room where Walter Reed died. Either he or
I will write to the Commanding Officer of the Army War College requesting old
maps showing the floor plan of this building as of 1902 and as more recently
changed. If we are unable to obtain such plans (they may not be easy to find)
may we ask you kindly to send to us a rough sketch of the entire second floor
floor plan and its relation with the downstairs front entrance.

In order that you may know a little about Walter Reeds contribution,
I am sending you by separate post a reprint which I hope will interest you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
